title: Computers are to design as microwaves are to cooking
content:
Hi guys, I am currently working on a typography project and desperately seeking inspiration. This quote by the great Milton Glaser 'Computers are to design as microwaves are to cooking' is my starting point and I am to create a typeface to enhance the semantic meaning of the words and create emotion. I am to consider the shape and form of each letterform as well as what materials to use to express my chosen quote. The brief encourages to use either/or all hand drawn, hand made, illustrated, painted, scratched, sewn, constructed, three dimensional type. We may combine the type with images but allow the letterforms to focus on the design. Overall broaden the sense of meaning of the words.

So research has taken me to obvious ideas and food for thought so far, like - radiation as the typeface / use of computer and microwave food related typefaces and symbols / microwave parts and components / Milton Glaser typefaces like stencil / microwave food packaging / circuit boards and computer parts / using the computer desktop or/and icons / using blur-motion to create speed / even microwaving computers and parts!....

I haven't hit the nail on the head yet but would very much welcome any input any one might have on this topic?!
author: matterst

comments.content:
IMHO, what Glaser is saying is that, like microwave has affected our cooking (too many under forty today can not cook a decent meal if their life dependet on it), computer has – like microwave, by lowering the standard – eaten away the classic knowledge and craft of typographic design.

So, perhaps you should just do a really poor job in 120 seconds. :·)

A computer is just a tool. Giving someone a pencil and paper doesn't make them a brilliant artist.

Nick Cooke
I think he's referring to how old food gets caked in on both of them. Spaghetti sauce all over the microwave and way too many office lunches in the keyboard of the computer.
Or perhaps "if you put something bad in it, it will explode".

What about the tactile? Seems microwave cooking is a sort of hands-off, no mess, no fuss way of cooking--sort of like the difference between kneading dough by hand and using an electric mixer instead. I don't think that the difference is as extreme between pencil and paper vs. computer, but there is still a tactile difference.  
The computer is a tool, but it's a different kind of tool, there seems more distance between the hand and the letterform.
\*snip\*

I'd start with another quote.

Ol' Milton has never gotten over the influence of the computer on the design business. Every lecture he gives, he sounds crankier and crankier, always crapping on digital tools. He had his time, I think his time has passed.

I don't think he understand cooking or computers.
Can the microwave be used as a design tool? Hmm...
@matterst: You are not going to do this design project with a computer, are you?

Cheers!

If art direction and design worked now the way it did back then, we wouldn't use computers ourselves. Someone else would do it for us. Somewhere along the way, we all ended up being equipment operators. Not everybody likes this arrangement. (I do.)

\> Computers are to design as microwaves are to cooking...

"At the times he made that comment, Glaser had valid point. With the introduction of digital technology, much of the graphic design being created was essentially a reheated, re-served version of what had been made earlier, using traditional methods......."

and the rest: Digital illustration by Lawrence Zeegen (p.66).

\> Computers are to design as microwaves are to cooking...

He has a point. Both computers and microwaves are based on technology recovered from the Roswell crash site.
I think what Milton Glaser meant to say is that "DAFONT is to design as microwaves are to cooking."

\> we all ended up being equipment operators. Not everybody likes this arrangement

Generally the ones who don't know how to use the computer.

I can't imagine going back to a design process where you specified type one day, got it the next, found it too big/small/wrong looking, spec'd a replacement, got that the next day, etc.

I miss wax machines

(No, not really)

You should ask Milton Glaser how he feels about that quote today. Like Licko’s “People read best what they read most,” the phrase has become one of those notorious moments in design punditry that was rehashed out of context until it took on a new meaning. It’s no longer relevant because Milton Glaser said it. It’s relevant because people resort to quotes when they want to be dismissive but can’t or won’t come up with a good argument.

Right.  
Never mind the artspeak BS, typographic interpretation of a celebrity quote is pure kitsch.  
It's like program music.

Design is not fundamentally expressive, and your teacher is leading you up the garden path.

I'm surprised this thread went on this long without someone noting that not only are computers bad for type design, but so is the pantograph. Fonts should be designed by punch-cutting!

That battle, though, I think, has been lost. The general public, whatever one might think of its standards of taste, is much too used to the slickness of today's typefaces to accept the results of punch-cutting by hand. They will accept that Aldus' Hypnerotomachia Poliphilii was an improvement on what came before, but even while acknowledging its beauty, they will still resolutely prefer, say, Times Roman for normal use.

That being said, though, it does seem to me that computer type design is in its infancy. I would prefer to draw letters on paper, and then measure them, and locate reference points in the letters I create by number, at least in some cases, than try to design a font by drawing directly on the computer screen with a mouse. And the fact that all the major outline font standards restrict one to using only spline curves rather than (at least for classic Roman fonts) being able to explicitly demand a conic section (never mind Melior, based on Piet Hein's superellipse) is a problem as well.
That's all very interesting, but I take it you're not a type designer.

That is like saying Art got worse after they invented the pencil.  
It’s just a tool that helps to facilitate creativity, it is one option to express and explore ideas and produce artwork, not the only option.  
The problem is to many people rely on it as their only medium of communicating and visualising their ideas and don’t explore other craft based mediums. It is not the computers fault!
